catalyst.source: Well-designed 3D/2D WO 3 /g-C 3 N 4 microspheres with an effective interfacial contact, synthesized through facile single step hydrothermal method, for stimulating photocatalytic CO 2 reduction under visible light has been investigated.
catalyst.context: Well-designed 3D/2D WO 3 /g-C 3 N 4 microspheres with an effective interfacial contact, synthesized through facile single step hydrothermal method, for stimulating photocatalytic CO 2 reduction under visible light has been investigated.The direct growth of WO 3 microspheres with g-C 3 N 4 enables good interaction among the both semiconductors, enabling proficient charge carrier separation.Highest CO and CH 4 production over WO 3 /g-C 3 N 4 of 145 and 133 mole g -1 h -1 was achieved, 1.91 and 4.03-fold higher than using pristine g-C 3 N 4 , respectively.This enhanced photoactivity was noticeable due to the synergistic effect with the larger interfacial contact area and proficient charge carrier separation.More importantly, CH 4 and CO production was increased by 2.51 and 1.64-fold with optimized H 2 O/CO 2 feed ratio due to efficient adsorption of both the reactants.Similarly, by replacing water with H 2 , CO 2 reduction efficiency was increased by 1.5 and 2.6-fold higher for CO and CH 4 production.The photon flux also has a significant contribution in CO 2 reduction, whereas, 1.6 and 1.7fold higher CO and CH 4 production observed by increasing light intensity.The stability analysis reveals continuous production of CO and CH 4 in cycles without any obvious deactivation under both the lower and higher light intensity.This work demonstrates a new approach to construct composite heterojunction and would be beneficial for further investigation in selective CO 2 conversion to solar fuels.

These findings were further described on the process of adsorption competition between CO 2 and H 2 O reactants over the catalyst active sites 48.It could be seen that yield of CO and CH 4 was increased by increasing H 2 O/CO 2 feed until reaching to maximum, then production was declined.At lower H 2 O/CO 2 feed ratio, there would be more CO 2 adsorption over the catalyst surface with smaller amount of H 2 O vapors attached to the catalyst active sites.Under such conditions, oxidation process for the production of H would not be efficient.Similarly, at very high H 2 O/CO 2 feed ratios, there would be more H 2 O molecules attached to the catalyst surface, and CO 2 has to compete with H 2 O molecules to adsorb over the catalyst active sites, resulting in slower reduction process.This reveals that excessive attachment of H 2 O or CO 2 molecules over the catalyst surface retarded the redox (oxidation and reduction) reactions, resulting in lower photocatalytic activity for CO and CH 4 production.Previously, similar observations have been reported during photocatalytic CO 2 reduction at different H 2 O/CO 2 feed ratio for the production of CO and CH 4 under visible light 27,47.According to thermodynamics, for CO production, 2 protons (H ) are required, whereas, one mole of CH 4 is produced by the involvement of 8 electrons and 8 protons during photocatalytic CO 2 reduction process.Thus, at lower H 2 O/CO 2 molar feed ratio, number of protons produced were not sufficient to promote CH 4 production, however, when H 2 O/ CO 2 feed ratio was increased, more protons would be produced during water oxidation process, thus, enabling appreciable amount of methane formation. Since the stability of photocatalysts has significant index for practical applications, the photoactivity of WO 3 /g-C 3 N 4 composite was conducted in multiple cycles by repeating the experiments under the identical reaction conditions.The stability tests were conducted using two different light intensities i.e., 20 and 100 mW cm -2 and the results are presented in Fig. 12.As demonstrated in Fig. 12 (a), continuous generation of CO and CH 4 was found in all the three cycles.More importantly, in the first cycle, CO and CH 4 production were much closer, whereas, production rates of both CO and CH 4 was increased in the 2nd and 3rd cyclic runs.The CO production of 1.64-fold higher was obtained than CH 4 evolution after 3rd cyclic run.Highest CO evolution of 598 mole g-cat -1 was acquired in the 3rd cycle, which is 1.28 and 2.1fold higher than it was produced in 2nd and 1st cyclic runs, respectively.Similarly, WO 3 /g-C 3 N 4 exhibits CH 4 evolution of 365 mole gcat -1 in 3rd cycle, which is 1.09 and 1.38 folds higher than it was produced in a 2nd and 1st cyclic runs, respectively.This demonstrates high stability of WO 3 /g-C 3 N 4 composite catalyst due to successful fabrication of heterojunction composite with larger exposed catalyst active surface area and faster charge carrier separation 12.The increased in yield rates of CO and CH 4 over the cyclic runs could be explained because of partial reduction of WO 3 and/or activation of adsorbed carbon species over the catalyst surface, resulting in more production of carbon-based products. lamp.context: First, graphitic carbon nitride was synthesized by heating melamine (Sigma Aldrich AR 99 ) at 550 C for 2 h under air atmosphere according to our previous work 29.Then, the sample was cooled to room temperature naturally.The bulk material obtained was grinded to fine powder and then was dispersed in nitric acid (1 M) and stirred for 24 h.Finally, samples were washed with DI water several times to remove acid and was named as protonated graphitic carbon nitride (g-C 3 N 4 ). For the synthesis of WO 3 modified g-C 3 N 4 , hydrothermal approach was employed.Initially, 2 g of Na 2 WO 4 2H 2 O was dissolved in 20 mL water and then 0.1 g Na 2 SO 4 was added and stirred for 60 min to get a homogenous suspension.Afterwards, g-C 3 N 4 dispersed in water (20 mL) was added into suspension.The pH of the solution was adjusted below 2 by adding 1 M HCl under continuous stirring until a paleyellow suspension was formed.The suspension was transferred to autoclave and heated to 180 C for 24 h and then naturally cooled to room temperature.The product obtained was centrifuged and washed with DI water to get pH 7. The sludge obtained was oven dried at 100 C under air flow and finally calcined at 400 C for 2 h and named as WO 3 / g-C 3 N 4 composite.The different amounts of WO 3 were adjusted by varying initial amounts of Na 2 WO 4 precursor.The pristine WO 3 was synthesized using the same procedure without the addition of g-C 3 N 4 .The schematic illustration for the synthesis of WO 3 /g-C 3 N 4 has been demonstrated in Fig. 1. The crystal structure of newly developed samples was studied by Xray diffraction (XRD, RIGAKU), operated with Cu-K radiation at 0.154178 nm, 40 kV and 30 mA.The morphologies and distribution of elements were obtained by scanning electron microscope (FESEM, ZEISS Crossbeam 340) and transmission electron microscope (TEM, HITACHI HT7700).The elemental states of the composite were determined by X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS, Axis Ultra DLD Shimazu).The optical properties were determined using UV-vis spectrophotometer (Cary 100 Agilent, Model G9821 A).The photoluminescence (PL) and Raman analysis were conducted (LabRAM HR Evolution, HORIBA) under 325 and 532 nm laser excitation source. The photocatalytic experiments were accompanied in a fixed bed photoreactor, made of stainless steel, according to our previous work 30.The light sources employed were 35 W HID car lamp and 300 W Xenon lamp with light intensity 20 and 100 mW cm -2 , respectively.A Pyrex glass of thickness 10 mm was used for passing the light irradiations and lamps were equipped with cooling fans to the remove lamp heat.Typically, 150 mg powder photo-catalyst was evenly introduced inside the stainless-steel chamber, equipped with a glass window at the top.The catalyst loading was varied from 50-250 mg to investigate the effect of different catalyst loadings on production rates and selectivity.The reactor was connected with a water saturator and vapors were carried by CO 2 , which is being passed through the water saturator, before entering into the reactor.The water saturator temperature was varied from 30 to 50 C to get different H 2 O/CO 2 molar feed ratios (H 2 O/CO 2 of 0.2, 0.4, and 0.60) in the gaseous feed mixture.Compressed CO 2 (99.99 ), N 2 (99.99 ) and H 2 (99.99 ) were regulated by mass flow controllers (MFC).For the investigation of photocatalytic CO 2 reduction with H 2 , both the gases were mixed in a gas mixture, before entering into the reactor.The CO 2 and H 2 were regulated at a flow rate 20 mL min -1 , having feed ratio 1.0.All the photocatalysts were tested without providing external heat and at atmospheric pressure.The gaseous products obtained after the reaction were analyzed using gas chromatography (GC-Agilent Technologies 6890 N, USA) equipped with a thermal conductivity detector (TCD) and a flame ionized detector (FID).A gas-tight syringe was used for the injection of gaseous samples into the GC.The GC column employed was a Carboxen-1010 PLOT Capillary GC Column (L I.D. 30 m 0.53 mm) connected with both TCD and FID detectors.
